item.title: Goodbye, Volkswagen: China's New EV Winners
item.description: The new top dogs in China’s electric vehicle market are starting to thin out the pack. Tesla is in the running, but most other foreign brands aren’t.

item.title: Metals Slip After Fed Signals Higher Interest Rates to Come
item.description: Base metals were slightly weaker and gold flat, with Peak Trading Research citing the hawkish Fed minutes as a tailwind for the dollar and a headwind for most commodity markets.

item.title: Global Atmosphere, Ocean Temperatures Break Records in June
item.description: The global surface temperature was .95 degrees Fahrenheit above the 1991-2020 average, beating the previous record, set in June 2019.

item.title: US Data Need to Be Very Weak to Push Dollar Lower
item.description: Upcoming data will need to be significantly weak to change rate expectations and cause lasting dollar falls, ING said, after Wednesday’s minutes left “no reason to doubt the Fed will go ahead with a July hike.”

item.title: Oil Steady as Market Process Production Cuts
item.description: Crude oil prices continued to remain largely rangebound, as production cuts from OPEC offset weak demand.

item.title: Bang & Olufsen Cautious on Outlook After Profit Miss
item.description: Bang & Olufsen posted a fourth-quarter net profit of DKK11 million and forecast full-year EBIT margin growth of 0%-6%, warning that uncertainty will continue in the coming year.

item.title: Malaysia's Central Bank Maintains Policy Rate at 3.0%
item.description: Malaysia’s central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged on the country’s moderating economic growth and easing inflation.

item.title: America's Green Skills Gap Raises Concerns About Energy Transition
item.description: In 2022, U.S. green job postings on LinkedIn jumped 20%, but green talent grew only 8.4%

item.title: Eurozone Bond Yields Rise as German Manufacturing Orders Jump in May
item.description: Eurozone government bond yields moved higher after German manufacturing orders came in significantly stronger than expected in May, and while the Fed minutes showed a divided committee to some degree, analysts said.

item.title: German Manufacturing Orders Rise, Sharply Outpace Forecasts
item.description: New orders at German factories rose 6.4% in May, suggesting the country’s key manufacturing sector could help it out of a recession in the second quarter.

item.title: Nikkei Falls 1.7%, Dragged by Electronics Stocks
item.description: Japanese stocks ended lower, dragged by falls in electronics stocks as concerns resurface about further tightening from the Fed.

item.title: Russian Jets Confront U.S. Drones Over Syria
item.description: The Russian fighters dropped flares in actions the U.S. described as unsafe and unprofessional.

item.title: What Sweden Could Mean for NATO, and for Russia
item.description: As Sweden waits for NATO to approve its membership, WSJ’s Sune Engel Rasmussen explains what the country can bring to the alliance and why Turkey and Hungary are blocking its application.

item.title: The West Again Learns That War Needs Industry
item.description: To handle newly aggressive adversaries without exploding national budgets, Washington and its allies need to try fresh approaches to developing, buying and maintaining military supplies.

item.title: Mar-a-Lago surveillance footage showed a Trump aide moving dozens of boxes in the days before DOJ investigators visited the property in June 2022 to retrieve records, according to newly unredacted portions of a search warrant request.
item.description: Mar-a-Lago surveillance footage showed a Trump aide moving dozens of boxes in the days before DOJ investigators visited the property in June 2022 to retrieve records, according to newly unredacted portions of a search warrant request.

item.title: Hong Kong police arrested four men accused of violating the city's national-security law as authorities intensified an effort to quash dissent, including targeting activists abroad.
item.description: Hong Kong police arrested four men accused of violating the city’s national-security law as authorities intensified an effort to quash dissent, including targeting activists abroad.

item.title: An Iraqi militia linked to Iran has taken hostage a Princeton researcher who is an Israeli citizen, the Israeli government said, creating another potential flashpoint between Israel and Tehran.
item.description: An Iraqi militia linked to Iran has taken hostage a Princeton researcher who is an Israeli citizen, the Israeli government said, creating another potential flashpoint between Israel and Tehran.

item.title: North Korea's spy satellite, which exploded midflight in May and fell into the Yellow Sea, couldn't be used for military purposes, according to a South Korean analysis of the recovered debris.
item.description: North Korea’s spy satellite, which exploded midflight in May and fell into the Yellow Sea, couldn’t be used for military purposes, according to a South Korean analysis of the recovered debris.

item.title: The Defense Department warned against overly restricting military personnel's access to national secrets in the aftermath of a massive leak of classified documents, even as it acknowledged the need to improve safeguards.
item.description: The Defense Department warned against overly restricting military personnel’s access to national secrets in the aftermath of a massive leak of classified documents, even as it acknowledged the need to improve safeguards.

item.title: Russian forces are badly depleted but Ukraine's counteroffensive is off to a slow, grinding start, Kyiv's Western allies say, as stiffer-than-expected Russian resistance and a lack of air cover have dashed hopes of a swift breakthrough.
item.description: Russian forces are badly depleted but Ukraine’s counteroffensive is off to a slow, grinding start, Kyiv’s Western allies say, as stiffer-than-expected Russian resistance and a lack of air cover have dashed hopes of a swift breakthrough.
